lesson1.title: The Restoration
lesson1.topic1: God is Your Loving Heavenly Father
lesson1.topic2: The Gospel Blesses Families and People
lesson1.topic3: Our Heavenly Father Reveals His Gospel
lesson1.topic1.desc:
God is your Heavenly Father. He knows you personally, even better than you know yourself. He knows your struggles, your deepest longings, and even the thoughts you keep in the depths of your heart. And most importantly: He loves you more than you can imagine. This love is not fleeting or conditional; it is eternal, constant, perfect.

His greatest desire is for you to be happy, not only now in this life full of trials and learning, but also for all eternity. To achieve this purpose, our Heavenly Father has provided a plan: the Gospel of Jesus Christ. Jesus Christ, His beloved Son, came to earth to teach us how to live, to show us the perfect example, and to give us the possibility of returning to the Father.

The Gospel is not just a set of commandments; it is a path of happiness and lasting peace.

lesson1.topic2.desc:
One of the greatest proofs that God loves us is that He gave us families. The family is the workshop of love, where we learn to forgive, to share, and to grow together. Although not all families are perfect, and sometimes we face conflicts or difficulties, God has promised that if we follow Jesus Christ, He will bless our home with greater unity and strength.

Current example: Imagine a family that decides to read the Scriptures together every night. At first, the children get distracted, some complain, and it seems like it doesn't work. But over time, those small seeds germinate into a spirit of love and unity in the home. This is the power of the Gospel in the family: it doesn't transform overnight, but with consistency it changes hearts and relationships.

In summary: God is your Heavenly Father, He loves you, and through Jesus Christ He offers you peace, purpose, and true joy in your personal and family life.

lesson1.topic3.desc:
God has never left us adrift. From the beginning of the world, He has chosen prophets to teach and guide His children. Adam, Noah, Abraham, and Moses were men called directly by Him.

Prophets have three essential missions:
• Teach about God and testify of Jesus Christ.
• Receive revelation or direction from the Lord.
• Guide the people and interpret the word of God.

The priesthood—the authority to act in God's name—was given to them to bless the children of men. When we follow the prophet, we receive blessings and protection; when we reject his words, we move away from God and fall into apostasy.

Current example: Think of a soccer coach who teaches strategies to his team. While they listen and apply his teachings, they win games. But if they decide to ignore him, they lose direction and fail. This is how the relationship with prophets works: while we follow his voice, we advance toward spiritual victory.

lesson1.topic4.desc:
More than 2,000 years ago, the most awaited promise was fulfilled: the Son of God came to the world. Jesus Christ lived a perfect life, without sin, and dedicated each day to serving, healing, teaching, and saving.

He did not come only to give advice; He came to establish His Church. He chose twelve apostles, conferred upon them the authority of the priesthood, and sent them to preach, baptize, and guide. He told Peter that upon the "rock" of revelation He would build His Church.

His mission culminated in the greatest sacrifice: the Atonement. In Gethsemane and on the cross, He bore the sins of all humanity, suffered and died so that we could be forgiven and have the hope of eternal life. And by rising again, He conquered death and opened the way for all to be resurrected.

Current example: Imagine a doctor who not only diagnoses a disease, but gives his own life to save the patients. That's what Christ did: He not only taught us the truth, but paid the price of our salvation.

lesson1.topic5.desc:
After the death of Jesus Christ and His apostles, came a dark period: the Great Apostasy. The apostles were persecuted and killed. With them, the authority of the priesthood was lost.

Although good people and scattered truths remained, the fullness of the Gospel was distorted. Many churches arose with contradictory teachings.

Current example: It's as if a teacher leaves his class and over time each student begins to invent their own version of the lesson. Over the years, what was clear and true becomes confusion.

Reformers like Martin Luther and John Calvin recognized errors and tried to correct them, but without the priesthood, they could not restore the fullness. A complete restoration was necessary.

lesson1.topic6.desc:
In 1820, a young man named Joseph Smith was seeking truth in the midst of many churches that contradicted each other. Following the invitation of James 1:5, he went to the woods to pray.

There he had a glorious vision known as the First Vision:

"I saw a pillar of light exactly over my head, above the brightness of the sun, which descended gradually until it fell upon me… When the light rested upon me I saw two Personages, whose brightness and glory defy all description, standing above me in the air. One of them spake unto me, calling me by name and said, pointing to the other—This is My Beloved Son. Hear Him!"

The Father and the Son appeared to Joseph, testifying that God still speaks with His children. They told him not to join any church, for all had lost the fullness. As in ancient times, God called a new prophet to restore His Gospel on earth.

lesson1.topic7.desc:
In 1829, Joseph Smith and Oliver Cowdery received the visit of John the Baptist, who conferred upon them the Aaronic Priesthood. Later, Peter, James, and John conferred upon them the Melchizedek Priesthood, thus returning the authority that Christ had given to His apostles.

With that authority, Joseph Smith organized again the Church of Jesus Christ on earth. Today, the President of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints is a living prophet, with the same authority as the ancient apostles.

This restoration of the priesthood means that sacred ordinances such as baptism, confirmation, and eternal marriage can be performed with God's authority, not just by good men, but by those who have been called and ordained by God Himself.

Current example: Just as a contract is validated with two signatures, God gave us two testaments: the Bible and the Book of Mormon, to confirm the truth of His plan.

The Book of Mormon contains the fullness of the gospel and testifies of Jesus Christ. It is tangible evidence that God still speaks with His children and that the Restoration is real.

lesson2.title: The Plan of Salvation
lesson2.topic1.desc:
Before we were born on this earth, we already existed. We were spirit sons and daughters of a loving God, our Heavenly Father. The Bible teaches us: "Before I formed thee in the belly I knew thee" (Jeremiah 1:5). This means that our existence did not begin on earth, but in a heavenly home full of love. There we learned who our Heavenly Father was and received from Him the greatest gift: the opportunity to come to earth.

The Book of Mormon confirms this truth: "And this is the manner after which they were ordained—being called and prepared from the foundation of the world according to the foreknowledge of God" (Alma 13:3). We are not accidents of the universe, but part of a divine plan drawn up before creation.

Imagine a family carefully preparing for the arrival of a child: they decorate the room, buy clothes and toys, and dream about their future. Thus, our Heavenly Father prepared this world for us, with everything necessary for us to grow and learn.

Remembering that we are children of God gives us identity and purpose. In a world that often labels us according to appearance, money, or achievements, knowing that we are children of an eternal King gives us confidence and hope.

lesson2.topic2: What is my purpose in life?
lesson2.topic2.desc:
Life has a greater purpose than simply "being born, working, and dying." The Scriptures teach: "Adam fell that men might be; and men are, that they might have joy" (2 Nephi 2:25). God desires that we be happy, but true happiness comes from living the Gospel of Jesus Christ.

Our time on earth is like a school. Here we learn to distinguish good from evil, to develop faith, to love, to serve, and to overcome trials. Just as an athlete strengthens by facing resistance, we become spiritually stronger by facing challenges.

Families are an essential part of this purpose. God instituted the family to teach us to love, to forgive, and to serve. Although no family is perfect, following Jesus Christ helps us strengthen family bonds.

Modern example: A young person may face the temptation to follow their friends in wrong decisions. By remembering that their purpose is to follow Christ, they find the strength to choose what is right. These kinds of small decisions prepare us to return to God.

lesson2.topic3: Where will I go after this life?
lesson2.topic3.desc:
We will all face death, but it is not the end. The Book of Mormon teaches: "The souls of all men… are taken home to that God who gave them life" (Alma 40:11). After we die, our spirit goes to the spirit world: a place of peace for the righteous and of learning for those who have not yet accepted the Gospel.

Thanks to Jesus Christ, we will all be resurrected. Paul testified: "For as in Adam all die, even so in Christ shall all be made alive" (1 Corinthians 15:22). Resurrection means that our body and spirit will be united again, never to be separated.

Imagine saying goodbye to a loved one at a funeral. The Gospel teaches that this separation is temporary, like when a child goes on a trip. The hope of seeing them again thanks to Christ brings comfort and peace even in the midst of pain.

After resurrection, we will be judged according to our works and the desires of our hearts. God prepared different degrees of glory (see 1 Corinthians 15:40–42) to reward His children in a just and perfect way.

lesson2.topic4: What does the plan mean for me?
lesson2.topic4.desc:
God's plan is not just an abstract doctrine; it touches every aspect of our lives. It gives us hope in illness, peace in suffering, and direction in confusion.

Jesus Himself said: "In the world ye shall have tribulation: but be of good cheer; I have overcome the world" (John 16:33). Understanding the plan helps us see that our trials are not punishments, but opportunities to grow.

Example: A single mother struggling to support her children can find strength by remembering that her effort has an eternal purpose. A young person who feels alone can remember that they have a Heavenly Father who knows them by name.

The plan also invites us to make wise decisions. When we know that life continues after death, we value more how we use our time, how we treat others, and how we cultivate our relationship with God.

The Book of Mormon adds: "And when ye shall receive these things, I would exhort you that ye would ask God, the Eternal Father, in the name of Christ, if these things are not true; and if ye shall ask with a sincere heart, with real intent, having faith in Christ, he will manifest the truth of it unto you, by the power of the Holy Ghost" (Moroni 10:4).

How to pray:
• Address God as your Father.
• Express to Him what you feel, your doubts and gratitude.
• Ask Him specifically to show you the truth.
• Close the prayer in the name of Jesus Christ.

The answer may come as a feeling of peace, a clear thought, or a gentle impression. The apostle Paul described this: "The fruit of the Spirit is love, joy, peace" (Galatians 5:22).

lesson2.topic6.desc:
Apostasy: Turning away from truth and rejecting God's prophets.

Atonement: The sacrifice of Jesus Christ that allows us to be forgiven.

Resurrection: Eternal union of body and spirit after death.

Revelation: Communication between God and His children.

Priesthood: Authority given by God to act in His name.

Gospel: God's plan centered on Jesus Christ.

These terms are fundamental to understanding the Plan of Salvation. Each one represents an essential part of the doctrine that helps us understand our eternal purpose and how God works in our lives.

The Plan of Salvation answers the deepest questions: Where did I come from? Why am I here? Where am I going? Knowing that we are children of God gives us hope. Trusting in Christ gives us peace. And following His Gospel prepares us to return to the heavenly home.

The final invitation is clear: pray, study the Book of Mormon, and seek to know Jesus Christ personally. If you do, you will discover that this plan is not just doctrine… it is the story of your life and the key to your eternal happiness!

Each day we live is an opportunity to draw closer to our Heavenly Father. Every decision we make can strengthen our faith or distance us from Him. The plan gives us direction, purpose, and hope in a world that often seems to lack meaning.

Remember: you are not alone on this journey. Your Heavenly Father knows you, loves you, and is ready to help you at every step of the way.

lesson3.title: The Gospel of Jesus Christ
lesson3.topic1.desc:
Faith is the first principle of the Gospel. It is not just believing that Christ existed, but trusting fully in Him and in His power to save us. As the Book of Mormon teaches: "There shall be no other name given nor any other way nor means whereby salvation can come unto the children of men" (Mosiah 3:17).

Faith is like a seed (Alma 32). When we water it with prayer, study, and obedience, it grows into a strong tree that bears fruit: hope, peace, and courage to face trials.

Modern example: A young person struggling with anxiety finds strength by repeating in their mind the words of Christ: "Come unto me, all ye that labour and are heavy laden, and I will give you rest" (Matthew 11:28). By putting their trust in Jesus, they learn to face their fear with faith, not despair.

Repentance is a gift of love. It does not mean just feeling remorse, but changing direction to draw closer to God. The prophet Alma explained it this way: "The Lord found me in a state of rebellion… and my soul was redeemed from the bitter pain" (Alma 36:17–20).

Daily repentance is like cleaning a mirror: we remove the stains of sin to see clearly the reflection of Christ in us.

Modern example: A person who lies at work feels burdened in their conscience. By deciding to confess, correct, and ask for forgiveness, they not only regain the trust of others, but feel the peace of divine forgiveness.

Baptism is the gateway to the Gospel path. Jesus Himself set the example by being baptized by John (Matthew 3:13–17). When we are baptized by immersion and with priesthood authority, we make a covenant with God: we promise to follow Christ, keep His commandments, and remember His sacrifice.

The Book of Mormon teaches: "Come and be baptized unto repentance, that ye may be washed from your sins" (Mosiah 18:10).

Modern example: A mother who decides to be baptized not only changes her life, but opens a new future for her children. Her decisions of faith create a legacy that transforms generations.

lesson3.topic4: The gift of the Holy Ghost
lesson3.topic4.desc:
After baptism, we receive confirmation through the laying on of hands: the gift of the Holy Ghost. Jesus promised: "And I will pray the Father, and he shall give you another Comforter" (John 14:16).

This gift is like having a spiritual compass always available. It comforts us in sorrow, warns us in danger, and confirms the truth.

The Spirit speaks softly, often as clear thoughts or feelings of peace (3 Nephi 11:3–5).

Modern example: A young person feels a strong impulse to change their route when returning home. Later they discover there was an accident on the route they usually take. The Spirit protected them without the need for audible words.

lesson3.topic5.desc:
The Gospel is not just an event, it is a lifelong journey. Jesus said: "But he that shall endure unto the end, the same shall be saved" (Matthew 24:13).

Enduring means remaining faithful despite challenges, trusting in Christ in the midst of adversity, and renewing our commitment to Him each day.

Modern example: A woman facing a serious illness finds strength by praying and studying the Scriptures daily. Although her body suffers, her faith remains firm, and that makes her a beacon of hope for her family.

lesson3.topic6.desc:
The Gospel of Jesus Christ includes sacred ordinances that mark our spiritual progress: baptism, confirmation, the Sacrament, and later, temple ordinances. Each ordinance is a reminder of our covenant with God and a step toward eternal life.

The Savior instituted the Sacrament so that we might remember His sacrifice (Luke 22:19–20). By participating worthily, we renew our promises to follow Him and receive spiritual strength.

Modern example: By taking the Sacrament each Sunday, a father feels renewed in his commitment to be more patient and loving in his home.

lesson3.topic7.desc:
The result of living the Gospel is true joy. Not a fleeting joy like the world offers, but a deep joy that fills the soul even in the midst of trials.

Jesus declared: "These things have I spoken unto you, that my joy might remain in you, and that your joy might be full" (John 15:11).

The prophet Nephi testified: "My soul delighteth in the things of the Lord" (2 Nephi 4:16).

Modern example: A family that decides to live the Gospel finds joy by serving together in their community. They discover that true happiness comes by forgetting self and focusing on others.

The Gospel of Jesus Christ is the path to eternal joy. It is a process: having faith in Him, repenting daily, being baptized and receiving the Holy Ghost, and enduring faithfully to the end. Those who follow this path not only find peace in this life, but the promise of eternal life in the presence of God.

lesson4.title: Gospel Commandments
lesson4.topic1.desc: The law of chastity is a sacred commandment that protects moral purity and family holiness. It means abstaining from sexual relations outside of marriage between a man and a woman, and maintaining clean thoughts, words, and actions. Jesus taught: 'Blessed are the pure in heart: for they shall see God' (Matthew 5:8). In a world saturated with pornography, immorality, and messages that trivialize the body, living this commandment is an act of spiritual courage. The Book of Mormon warns: 'Lust is the cause of many calamities among the children of men' (Jacob 2:28). By keeping the law of chastity, we invite the Holy Ghost to remain with us, protect our future marriage, and demonstrate true love, which is based on respect and commitment. Modern example: a young man who decides not to view pornography, despite peer pressure, discovers a clearer mind, greater self-confidence, and increased spiritual sensitivity.

lesson4.topic2.desc: The Word of Wisdom is the law of health that God revealed to protect our body and mind. It teaches us to avoid alcohol, tobacco, illegal drugs, coffee and tea, and to use good foods prudently. The promise is clear: 'And shall run and not be weary, and shall walk and not faint' (D&C 89:20). In a time when excessive substance consumption destroys families and societies, this commandment preserves us. Modern example: a mother who stops drinking alcohol discovers greater mental clarity and can better care for her children. The Book of Mormon teaches that 'men should be temperate in all things' (Mosiah 4:27). Living the Word of Wisdom is an act of faith that prepares us to serve God better.

The prophet Malachi taught: 'Prove me now herewith... if I will not open you the windows of heaven' (Malachi 3:10). Tithing finances God's work: building temples, chapels, teaching materials, and missionary work. Modern example: a young man who just starts working decides to pay his tithing even though he has little. He discovers that his resources go further and feels joy knowing that he contributes to the Lord's work. The Book of Mormon also teaches: 'All those who were willing to take upon them the name of Christ... gave of their substance' (Mosiah 18:27). Tithing is a covenant of mutual trust between us and God.

'Remember the sabbath day, to keep it holy' (Exodus 20:8). In the Book of Mormon, God's people also observed the holy day and found joy in gathering to worship (Mosiah 18:25). Modern example: a family decides to turn off screens and dedicate Sunday to attending Church, singing hymns, and sharing testimonies at home. That day becomes a spiritual refuge in the middle of the week. Keeping the Sabbath Day renews, strengthens, and unites us more with God.

Modern example: a young man who begins the habit of reading 10 minutes each morning in the Book of Mormon discovers answers to school questions and strength to resist peer pressure. lesson4.topic7.desc: The Ten Commandments were given to Moses on Sinai and remain valid today as a universal moral guide. Jesus Christ summarized the law in two great commandments: love God and love your neighbor (Matthew 22:37–39). The Book of Mormon confirms that these commandments are eternal (Mosiah 13:12–24). Modern example: a businessman who decides to be honest in his taxes even though others cheat feels the peace of conscience and God's trust. Keeping the Ten Commandments strengthens families, communities, and entire nations.

lesson5.title: Covenants and Ordinances of the Gospel
lesson5.topic1.desc: Baptism is the first ordinance of the Gospel and the gateway to eternal life. Jesus Christ taught: 'Except a man be born of water and of the Spirit, he cannot enter into the kingdom of God' (John 3:5). In the Book of Mormon, Alma taught that baptism symbolizes our covenant to follow Christ (Mosiah 18:8–10). Modern example: a young man who decides to be baptized after months of study feels a deep peace and joy that confirms his decision. Baptism by immersion and by proper authority is essential for salvation.

Amos taught: 'Surely the Lord God will do nothing, but he revealeth his secret unto his servants the prophets' (Amos 3:7). In the Book of Mormon, Nephi showed obedience to the prophet of his time when he said: 'I will go and do the things which the Lord hath commanded' (1 Nephi 3:7). Following the prophet does not mean idolizing a man, but trusting that God speaks through him. Modern example: a young man who hears the prophet's invitation to leave social media for a time discovers more mental peace and time for his family. By following the prophet, we receive protection against the changing philosophies of the world.

Paul explained that 'no man taketh this honour unto himself, but he that is called of God' (Hebrews 5:4). In the Book of Mormon, Alma ordained priests to teach the word of God (Mosiah 18:18). Auxiliary organizations (such as Relief Society, Young Men, Young Women, and Primary) support this work and strengthen families. Modern example: a young man who receives the Aaronic Priesthood participates in preparing the sacrament, blessing the life of the entire congregation. The priesthood and its complementary organizations are essential for building the kingdom of God.

In Eden it was declared: 'Therefore shall a man leave his father and his mother, and shall cleave unto his wife' (Genesis 2:24). The Book of Mormon emphasizes that happiness is found in living according to God's commandments within the home (Mosiah 2:41). Modern example: a couple who prays together every night and studies the Scriptures as a family creates a spiritual refuge for their children. Marriage and family centered on Christ strengthen society and prepare people for eternal life.

The temple is a place where heaven touches earth, and its ordinances unite us as eternal families.

lesson5.topic7.desc: Enduring to the end means remaining faithful to Christ and His commandments throughout our entire life. The Book of Mormon clarifies that we must 'press forward with a steadfastness in Christ' (2 Nephi 31:20). Modern example: a Church member who faces years of illness continues to trust in the Lord, serving in what they can and attending Church when their health allows. Enduring to the end is not a momentary effort, but a constant commitment that ensures eternal joy in God's presence.

lesson6.title: The Articles of Faith
lesson6.topic1.desc: We believe in God, the Eternal Father, and in His Son, Jesus Christ, and in the Holy Ghost. This teaches that they are three distinct beings, united in perfect purpose. The Bible shows this truth in the baptism of Jesus, when the Father spoke from heaven, the Son was baptized, and the Spirit descended like a dove (Matthew 3:16–17). The Book of Mormon also confirms this doctrine (3 Nephi 11:27). Modern example: when we pray, we direct our words to the Father, in the name of Christ, and receive answers through the Holy Spirit.
lesson6.topic1.scriptureMain: And when they had done this, Jesus said unto them: Come unto me and be baptized in my name, for thus hath the Father commanded me, that ye may be sanctified by the reception of the Holy Ghost, that ye may stand spotless before me at the last day. (3 Nephi 11:27)
lesson6.topic1.more.0: Matthew 3:16–17 — "And Jesus, when he was baptized, went up straightway out of the water: and, lo, the heavens were opened unto him, and he saw the Spirit of God descending like a dove, and lighting upon him: And lo a voice from heaven, saying, This is my beloved Son, in whom I am well pleased."
lesson6.topic1.more.1: John 17:21 — "That they all may be one; as thou, Father, art in me, and I in thee, that they also may be one in us: that the world may believe that thou hast sent me."
lesson6.topic1.more.2: Acts 7:55–56 — "But he, being full of the Holy Ghost, looked up stedfastly into heaven, and saw the glory of God, and Jesus standing on the right hand of God, And said, Behold, I see the heavens opened, and the Son of man standing on the right hand of God."
lesson6.topic1.more.3: D&C 130:22 — "The Father has a body of flesh and bones as tangible as man's; the Son also; but the Holy Ghost has not a body of flesh and bones, but is a personage of Spirit."
lesson6.topic2.desc: We believe that men will be punished for their own sins, and not for Adam's transgression. This means that each person is responsible before God for their own decisions. We do not inherit Adam's guilt, although we do live in a fallen world with its consequences. The Book of Mormon teaches that men are free to choose liberty and eternal life, or captivity and death (2 Nephi 2:25–27). Modern example: a person is not judged by their parents' mistakes, but by their own choices.
lesson6.topic2.scriptureMain: And men are free according to the flesh; and all things are given them which are expedient unto man. And they are free to choose liberty and eternal life, through the great Mediator of all men, or to choose captivity and death, according to the captivity and power of the devil. (2 Nephi 2:25–27)
lesson6.topic2.more.0: Ezekiel 18:20 — "The soul that sinneth, it shall die. The son shall not bear the iniquity of the father, neither shall the father bear the iniquity of the son."
lesson6.topic2.more.1: Romans 5:12 — "Wherefore, as by one man sin entered into the world, and death by sin; and so death passed upon all men, for that all have sinned."
lesson6.topic2.more.2: Moses 6:54 — "Therefore teach these things freely unto your children, saying, That by reason of transgression cometh the fall, which fall bringeth death, and inasmuch as ye were born into the world by water, and blood, and the spirit, which I have made, and so became of dust a living soul, even so ye must be born again into the kingdom of heaven, of water, and of the Spirit."
lesson6.topic2.more.3: Alma 42:7 — "And thus we see that man became a fallen being, and thus became a mortal, and a spiritual, being separated from God."
lesson6.topic3.desc: We believe that through the Atonement of Christ, all mankind may be saved, by obedience to the laws and ordinances of the Gospel. Christ's grace offers us salvation, but we must accept it by living His teachings. Nephi taught: 'It is by grace that we are saved, after all we can do' (2 Nephi 25:23). Modern example: someone who strives to keep the commandments, even though they make mistakes, trusts that Christ's grace lifts them up and gives them hope.
lesson6.topic3.scriptureMain: For by grace are ye saved through faith; and that not of yourselves: it is the gift of God: Not of works, lest any man should boast. (2 Nephi 25:23)
lesson6.topic3.more.0: John 3:16 — "For God so loved the world, that he gave his only begotten Son, that whosoever believeth in him should not perish, but have everlasting life."
lesson6.topic3.more.1: Mosiah 3:19 — "For the natural man is an enemy to God, and has been from the fall of Adam, and will be, forever and ever, unless he yields to the enticings of the Holy Spirit."
lesson6.topic3.more.2: Ephesians 2:8–10 — "For by grace are ye saved through faith; and that not of yourselves: it is the gift of God: Not of works, lest any man should boast."
lesson6.topic3.more.3: Alma 11:40 — "And he shall take upon him death, that he may loose the bands of death which bind his people; and he will take upon him their infirmities, that his bowels may be filled with mercy."
lesson6.topic4.desc: We believe that the first principles and ordinances of the Gospel are: first, Faith in the Lord Jesus Christ; second, Repentance; third, Baptism by immersion for the remission of sins; fourth, Laying on of hands for the gift of the Holy Ghost. This is the 'way' taught by Christ Himself in 2 Nephi 31. Modern example: an investigator who studies, repents, is baptized, and receives the Holy Spirit, begins a path of discipleship that accompanies them throughout their life.
lesson6.topic4.scriptureMain: And now, if the Lamb of God, he being holy, should have need to be baptized by water, to fulfil all righteousness, O then, how much more need have we, being unholy, to be baptized, yea, even by water! (2 Nephi 31:5–21)
lesson6.topic4.more.0: Acts 2:38 — "Then Peter said unto them, Repent, and be baptized every one of you in the name of Jesus Christ for the remission of sins, and ye shall receive the gift of the Holy Ghost."

lesson6.topic4.more.3: Moroni 8:10–12 — "Behold I say unto you that this thing shall ye teach—repentance and baptism unto those who are accountable and capable of committing sin."
lesson6.topic5.desc: We believe that a man must be called of God, by prophecy, and by the laying on of hands by those who are in authority, to preach the Gospel and administer in the ordinances thereof. This teaches that no one calls themselves to the ministry, but must be called in a divine manner. Modern example: a bishop receives his calling not because he offers himself, but because he is chosen through revelation and sustained by the congregation.
lesson6.topic5.scriptureMain: And no man taketh this honour unto himself, but he that is called of God, as was Aaron. (Hebrews 5:4)
lesson6.topic5.more.0: Exodus 28:1 — "And take thou unto thee Aaron thy brother, and his sons with him, from among the children of Israel, that he may minister unto me in the priest's office."

lesson6.topic5.more.3: 3 Nephi 11:21–22 — "And the Lord said unto them: Arise and come forth unto me, that ye may thrust your hands into my side."
lesson6.topic6.desc: We believe in the same organization that existed in the Primitive Church, namely, apostles, prophets, pastors, teachers, evangelists, and so forth. This organization ensures unity and divine direction. Modern example: the current Twelve Apostles fulfill the same function that Peter, James, and John did in the primitive Church.
lesson6.topic6.scriptureMain: And he gave some, apostles; and some, prophets; and some, evangelists; and some, pastors and teachers; For the perfecting of the saints, for the work of the ministry, for the edifying of the body of Christ. (Ephesians 4:11–14)

lesson6.topic6.more.3: Mosiah 18:18 — "And he commanded them that they should teach nothing save it were the things which he had taught, and which had been spoken by the mouth of the holy prophets."
lesson6.topic7.desc: We believe in the gift of tongues, prophecy, revelation, visions, healing, interpretation of tongues, and so forth. These gifts strengthen faith and edify the Church. Modern example: a missionary who learns a new language and testifies with power thanks to the Holy Spirit is receiving this gift.
lesson6.topic7.scriptureMain: And again, I exhort you, my brethren, that ye remember that every good gift cometh of Christ. (Moroni 10:8–18)
lesson6.topic7.more.0: 1 Corinthians 12:7–11 — "But the manifestation of the Spirit is given to every man to profit withal."

lesson6.topic7.more.3: 2 Nephi 32:2–3 — "Do ye not remember that I said unto you that after ye had received the Holy Ghost ye could speak with the tongue of angels?"
lesson6.topic8.desc: We believe the Bible to be the word of God as far as it is translated correctly; we also believe the Book of Mormon to be the word of God. Both are witnesses of Jesus Christ and complement each other. Modern example: reading the Bible about the resurrection and confirming it with 3 Nephi 11 in the Book of Mormon strengthens our faith in Christ.
lesson6.topic8.scriptureMain: And because my words shall hiss forth—many of the Gentiles shall say: A Bible! A Bible! We have got a Bible, and there cannot be any more Bible. (2 Nephi 29:8–10)
lesson6.topic8.more.0: John 10:16 — "And other sheep I have, which are not of this fold: them also I must bring, and they shall hear my voice."

lesson6.topic9.desc: We believe all that God has revealed, all that He does now reveal, and we believe that He will yet reveal many great and important things pertaining to the Kingdom of God. This teaches the importance of continuous revelation. Modern example: listening to the prophet in general conference is receiving modern revelation, just as Moses received the law on Sinai.
lesson6.topic9.scriptureMain: Surely the Lord God will do nothing, but he revealeth his secret unto his servants the prophets. (Amos 3:7)

lesson6.topic10.desc: We believe in the literal gathering of Israel and in the restoration of the Ten Tribes; that Zion (the New Jerusalem) will be built upon the American continent; that Christ will reign personally upon the earth; and, that the earth will be renewed and receive its paradisiacal glory. Modern example: the Church's efforts in missionary work and the gathering of Israel directly fulfill this prophecy.
lesson6.topic10.scriptureMain: And it shall come to pass that the Lord God shall commence his work among all nations, kindreds, tongues, and people, to bring about the restoration of his people upon the earth. (3 Nephi 20:29–32)

lesson6.topic11.desc: We claim the privilege of worshiping Almighty God according to the dictates of our own conscience, and allow all men the same privilege, let them worship how, where, or what they may. This doctrine defends religious freedom. Modern example: living peacefully in a community where there are Catholics, Evangelicals, and Mormons, recognizing each person's right to worship God according to their faith.
lesson6.topic11.scriptureMain: And if it seem evil unto you to serve the Lord, choose you this day whom ye will serve. (Joshua 24:15)

lesson6.topic12.desc: We believe in being subject to kings, presidents, rulers, and magistrates, in obeying, honoring, and sustaining the law. Being good citizens is part of being good disciples. Modern example: paying taxes even when it's difficult, recognizing that it's part of God's order for society.

lesson6.topic13.desc: We believe in being honest, true, chaste, benevolent, virtuous, and in doing good to all men; indeed, we may say that we follow the admonition of Paul—We believe all things, we hope all things, we have endured many things, and hope to be able to endure all things. If there is anything virtuous, lovely, or of good report or praiseworthy, we seek after these things. This article describes how the character of a true disciple of Christ should be. Modern example: a young person who avoids pornography, speaks respectfully, and helps others reflects this principle in action.
lesson6.topic13.scriptureMain: Finally, brethren, whatsoever things are true, whatsoever things are honest, whatsoever things are just, whatsoever things are pure, whatsoever things are lovely, whatsoever things are of good report; if there be any virtue, and if there be any praise, think on these things. (Philippians 4:8)
